description:
didn' work for me
my os is linux mint,version which has been updated to incorporated to import snap store apts can not register or setup

It renders the pointer tiny when using high resolution displays, which makes it difficult to use IMHO. I can't see a dark mode, but maybe it's in the Settings somewhere.

Without dark mode and accurate rendering I feel like just using Gmail in a browser with Dark Reader applied, which is a shame because Hey was looking a promising alternative... but it doesn't seem to be there just yet.
summary: Bugs with displaying at high resolution

description: So far I've had good experience with this new e-mail service. Brilliant ideas regarding screening e-mail and having very clear rules without having to set them up yourself. So far also have been impressed with the search function.
This client is a mail client that i have been waiting for on linux this is perfect and exactly what i have been wanting.
I was skeptical when I first signed up for hey!, but i'm completely sold. It has improved my life dratically and the service is worth every penny.
summary: Best thing to happen to email in ages!

description:
Thought I would give this new email client a try. Installed it on Ubuntu Budgie/Snap, launched it. It opened a screen that said "Welcome Back" and asked for my email and password. Of course it rejected what I entered, as I had not signed up. And there was no way to sign up for a new account, that I could see.

So....it's getting dumped, I don't care how cool the developers think they are.

You can't use this application to directly access your GMAIL account.
It appears that your emails will go through a third party provider.
Uninstall.
Also, it's not clear what happen to my emails before they reach my desktop.
It launches which at least is something.. It is unfortunately the only thing it can do
This app only works if you use their own paid-for email service. It looks great, but only if you want to pay $99 a year!
Cannot add my e-mail address... So it doesn't work. It's a waste of network traffic to consider downloading this program.

I feel like a lot of the other reviewers are confused about what this is - you need an account with HEY. It's not going to work if you put in a different email address.

My only gripe is that they could get rid of the superfluous menu bar, but otherwise it's great.
The native linux app works as expected and the functionality is the same as the Windows desktop, iOS and Android apps. No complaints.
summary: Great email service, client works very well

description:
This could do a better job of communicating that it's NOT just a client. You must use a Hey email account.

That said, the app and service is nice.

As far as Linux email apps go, the design is top-tier.
Especially the workflow around reading multiple emails, and "Paper trail" for those receipt emails you want to keep.
People are giving this 1 star probably because they though this is just an email client. This is the app made for HEY email users.
summary: This app is great. PS. This is NOT an email client

description: Decided to scrap my entire Gmail setup in favor of a single HEY account. Never going back. A great, simple email app that hides everything you don't need to see. Much more enjoyable to subscribe to newsletters or correspond with friends and family now, thanks to HEY.

Hey's approach to email makes keeping your email organized virtually effortless. If you have anxiety about your poorly organized email then Hey is worth paying for.

Hey is like having a really well thought out set of email filter rules, but without the constant hassle of having to set all that up or maintain it, with the result that email feels ridiculously easy.

It requires a hey.com account, so don't expect this app to connect with gmail, exchange, etc. (If needed you can still forward those emails to your hey.com address.)
